metadata.chief_complaint: ADHD evaluation, teacher concerns, parents disagree on severity

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi everyone. I understand you're here because of some concerns about Caleb's attention and behavior?

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Yes, his teacher has been worried. She sent home the Vanderbilt form you gave us.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I think the teacher is overreacting. He's a normal boy. Boys are hyper.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Mike, the teacher has been doing this for twenty years. I don't think she's overreacting.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me look at the forms and then hear from both of you. I want to understand what Caleb is like in different settings.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: So the teacher's Vanderbilt shows scores in the significant range for inattention and hyperactivity. She notes he can't stay seated, blurts out answers, and has trouble finishing assignments.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: That's every kid. You expect a seven-year-old to sit still for six hours?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You make a fair point. That's why we compare to other kids his age. The Vanderbilt has norms for that. His scores are higher than 95% of his peers.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: She also said he's behind in reading because he can't focus during instruction.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: Reading just takes longer for some kids.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: What's Caleb like at home? Let's start with you, Mom.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: It's hard. Homework takes forever because he can't sit still. He starts one thing, gets distracted, forgets what he was doing. He loses stuff constantly.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: He does fine when he's playing video games. He focuses on that for hours.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's actually consistent with ADHD. Kids with ADHD can hyperfocus on things they find highly stimulating, like video games. It's the boring, effortful tasks they struggle with.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: That makes sense. He can't focus on homework but can play Minecraft forever.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Dad, what's your experience with Caleb? When you're together, what's he like?

script.speaker: dad
script.text: He's fine. We play catch, ride bikes, go to his games. He's a great kid.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Those are all physical, active things. What about quieter activities? Does he sit through dinner? Through a movie?

script.speaker: dad
script.text: Well, he's up and down at dinner. Movies are hard unless it's something he really likes.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Can I play on your phone, Mom?

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Not right now, sweetie. We're talking to the doctor.

script.speaker: child
script.text: But I'm bored. This is boring.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hey Caleb, I have some paper and crayons in that drawer. Want to draw while we talk?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Okay.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me review the parent Vanderbilts. Mom, your form shows elevated scores for inattention and hyperactivity too. Dad, your scores are lower, but still showing some inattention symptoms.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I marked them lower because I don't think it's that bad.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It's actually common for parents to see things differently, especially when one parent does more of the homework and school stuff.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: That's mostly me.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: So you see more of the struggle. Dad sees more of Caleb at his best, during fun activities.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I'm not saying there's no issue. I just don't want him labeled and drugged up.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a really important concern, and I'm glad you said it. A diagnosis isn't a label, it's a roadmap. It helps us understand how his brain works and what supports he needs.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: But medication changes kids. I've heard stories.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Medication is one option, not the only option. And we wouldn't jump to that first anyway. There are behavioral strategies, school accommodations, and other approaches.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: So do you think he has ADHD?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Based on the Vanderbilt scores from both teachers and parents, and what I'm observing today, and the history you've shared, yes, I think Caleb meets criteria for ADHD, combined type, meaning both inattention and hyperactivity.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: What does that actually mean for him?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It means his brain's executive function, the part that helps with planning, focus, and impulse control, works differently. It's not a character flaw. It's neurobiology.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Here's what I recommend. First, we request a 504 plan at school for accommodations, like extra time on tests and preferential seating. Second, I'd like you to try some behavioral strategies at home. I'll give you a handout.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: What about medication?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let's try these things first and see how he does. If he's still really struggling in six to eight weeks, we can discuss whether medication would help. It's a tool, not a requirement.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: That seems reasonable. I can live with that.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Me too. Thank you for hearing us both out.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's my job. Let's schedule a follow-up in about eight weeks. And call sooner if anything changes.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Look, I drew a robot!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a cool robot, Caleb. Good job.
